tMND16ggWIqMDIHX55jGsg.text: My summer break in July: They made their own chilly oil! Yummmayyyy! The food is refine and variety of the menu was insanely tempting for over orders! Parents and me wanted lobster noodles with XO sauce and that was available upon request (it was so good even that filled up, cleaned the plate) The experience was amazing even before we entered the big black door, greeted by the front desk and was taken to our table. It looks like the hire in this place has "professional" requirements, you'll understand what I mean when you get there.  If I'm in London again, it'll be my first stop!

noZoMJ0kv89jTye4XulUyw.text: This place was amazing!  The vibe is very cool and chic. Our waiter was helpful in guiding our choices. This is quality Chinese food...so yummy!  The dim sum was not only beautiful but delicious. We ordered a crispy duck dish, porkfried rice and a wagyu beef dish. The beef was so tender that it literally melted in your mouth. Definitely worth going here!

jznRQzjmP3lsY-wWYoS-pA.text: Brilliant restaurant! This place can cater for every occasion, from a romantic evening with the lady friend to a catch up with friends. The food is simply perfect. A host of high end asian cusine done well! Its a little on the expensive side but you can see why when you get there a favourite with the celebs  the restaurant is extremely welcoming and the service is far beyond anyother place of its kind.I coukd nit pick and say that the outside of the building is a bit imposing but when everything exceeds expectations. .. why bother.

NBV5JUjrzcZd0M3-MHmqzQ.text: Excellent, bright and fun, you'd never know it was there from the outside! Book to avoid disappointment!bright and fun upstairs, downstairs, is for private and special parties! There's a lift if you can't do stairs, they use a card to swip!very new.the dim sum were superb. As was the crispy yummy duckGreat selections of fine wines for that special occasion,if you go upstairs,it's casual, downstairs, a bit more formal. Price wise, something to suit all, if not sure, stick to the lunch or evening special  menues Fantabulous Swanky is a good  word or trendy

o-A--g_7Fz80Xyj1UfltEA.text: This restaurant is posh and expensive And most importantly serves very good Chinese food However, I am a huge fan because you can walk in and get a table any time of the day even on weekend nights! An aspect that you can not dream of any more in London these days

2fJ8xKp-gMyalR5OLidxgg.text: Best dim sum in London! Yes, quite a claim but I've tried quite a few and this is as good as it gets. The restaurant is split into two sections, upstairs which has windows and lighter interior and the downstairs area which is like the other Hakkasan in Hanway Place. The staff were all very friendly and attentive, there wasn't any unnecessary wait at any point. Now to the dim sum. The Hakkasan main dishes can be quite pricey but I find that the dim sum is actually not too bad compared to other places. Considering the quality of the dim sum I'd happily pay the price. Well, maybe not every week. Some great ones were the Chinese chives and crabmeat steamed dumplings, little bundles of deliciousness. Very subtle flavours.The smoked duck and pumpkin dumplings were actually shaped into little mini pumpkins. The pumpkin and duck went really well together and being a fried dumpling the outside was perfectly crispy.The prawn and kai lan cheong fun had the best flavour I've encountered so far in London.Had a few more dim sum but these were the highlights. The Xiao Long Bao were good as well but a bit small. In addition to the dim sum a main dish was required and aubergine and tofu in black bean sauce hotpot was chosen. It turned out to be a great choice. The tofu was perfectly soft and the flavour was great.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

nvC2vJJ1vrT4Io4wJzXsFw.text: Bloody pricey, and I'm not sure I'd feel good letting someone else pay for me here, but if the company's paying - hell yeah!!Top class service, well chosen wine and scrummy cocktails left us drooling in anticipation of the main. My fellow diners and I followed the £50 set menu.The starter of dim sum was excellent (great variety), and the waitress helpfully lead us slowly through what was in each one, meaning I didn't end up sucking on a scallop by mistake!The standout main was the beef. Now I can't remember what this was called, but it came in an edible 'cone' and was meltingly tender and cooked in a gorgeous, sweet, rich sauce. The king prawns were also excellent, and huge.I think I was too deleriously full to remember the pudding, but there was chocolate involved.A really, really beautiful restaurant, with great, attentive staff, wonderful food, and everything else you would expect for this price bracket.

39Lba-co5IoOmD77o9Wa9w.text: Amazing food in London! Great ambiance and fabulous cocktails.  Food definitely lives up the hype.Dined there with a vegetarian friend yesterday, we ordered:  vegetarian dim sum; hot'n'sour soup; salt and pepper tofu; and I ordered stir-fried steak with merlot for my main dish.  To drink, I had a peach bellini.Everything was delicious, but the highlights were the vegetarian dim sum and the salt and pepper dim sum (and the bellini).Great place for vegetarians - they even have a vegetarian tasting menu.Highly recommend!

OiuoFu41Gt0_1n9Pzo39Yw.text: Super glam...cool vibe with Dj's playing even on weekdays but in a nice background hip way. Only came for the bar but the lychee martini drink was super refreshing, even if I only had a sip of my friends. Service was great and you can tell the barmen have some talent and few tricks up their sleeves. Plan to come back for the food soon, as I've heard very good things but great place to have a little after work drink with friends.

zGJZTiJ1JLCkRYJNVYe_Yg.text: I've never met a chilean seabass that I didn't like until I dined at Hakkasan in London.   Having dined at Hakkasan Miami, I was excited to go to Hakkasan London.  Quite a difference in the menu selections.   We ordered a few small plates to share, tapas style, and also the grill chilean seabass with chinese honey, and that was a big disappointment.  I was hoping for that dish to be as amazing as the one I had in Miami.  Let's be honest, it takes a lot to mess up such a great fish.  It was overcooked, and seasoning wasn't up to par.  The dessert menu leaves a lot to be desired. On the brighter side, service was really great. Would not come back to this location.

gNXrZ0MZ-UTeS7jjwItfUQ.text: Very good food and service.  A hip place, but comfortable too.  The plates are for sharing, and there are a lot of very good choices.  The flavors are bold and intense.  Good wine list too!  Would go back when next in London.

FG1dTDXDutdVsdFblv_V9Q.text: Sexy, Brilliant, and Yummy all rolled up into one!This place has it all; style, class, food to die for, and the service was impeccable!I'm not going to say much about this place, because in the few words I've already said, says it all!I am so recommending this place to family and friends and will be back for sure very soon!

iKCMODtm5BR49TUAi14YWA.text: Delicious food, amazing atmosphere, good service! I loved the dim sum! The perfection and the taste of all the dishes justifies the price. The service was also very good! One of the coolest restaurants I ever went to!

6fophzqMFAzpwxVfGQDrsQ.text: As a very regular and satisfied visitor of the original at Hanway Place I was eager to try this Mayfair branch. It was a bit disappointing. All was just slightly less perfect than at Hakkasan Nr.1: food, service, ambiance. If you do go, don't forget to ask for a table downstairs as the cellar feels more like the original.

hEb1Oq463nHNj7zjYwMTzQ.text: The restaurant is beautiful but the seating is a bit crowded. Overall, our meal was quite good, but I expected it to be better. I had the Pippa duck which was excellent. However, my husband ordered the Kobe beef rare and it came out medium to well. What chef on earth cooks Kobe to medium??? The fried rice was also nothing special, but it was fine. However, the desserts were incredible!! I had a chocolate hazelnut thing in a sphere and it was mind blowing. 4 stars for the happy ending.

72NyMV-ZRYdQCnUyT1ug1Q.text: Hakkasan Mayfair has great food and ambiance. We sat upstairs along the windows -- I hear the downstairs is closer to the original, but the space is nice and still filled with the beautiful people. I enjoyed the meal and the experience but ultimately for the price point I've had better.The homemade tofu fried was great, made of pumpkin which was quite original and surprisingly worked well. The cod with Chinese honey was good if a little heavier than expected. The aubergines and tofu claypot was one of my favorites. Mapo tofu is not so Sichuan, more of a Western version with a more black bean than Sichuan pepper spice. I liked the spicy shrimp but not because it was spicy.  Desserts were good not great.The sticker shock brought the stars down... We had three expensive bottles of wine, but I'm not sure it was worth 50 pounds a person without alcohol.

H0D9ESOSjCyRBuAdn053zQ.text: One of the best Chinese restaurant in town. Amazing music, nice crowed and good food. make sure to book in advance.

rQ11rqq0x1okEXEzpdfIrA.text: We were looking for a scene and my date's dress (and body) fit right in at Hakkasan. Cocktails were fun and she loved being recognized by the fashionistas at the bar. After a couple of dirty martini we enjoyed good Chinese food with above average service. Don't come here if you want a low profile or not be seen.

Zn6tUx5ikP0hQAaEJvV9TA.text: The restaurant has a luxurious ambient and they do an excellent job in presenting their dishes. However, I found the food to be good but nothing special. Their grilled honey glazed seabass was delicious though.

flZFnhc6tgn3-As4C6nMGA.text: Three stars because of the atmosphere, although I am tempted to give 2.  The crowd the Sunday night were were there was full of international tourists. The service was attentive, anyone will stop and help you if needed, but our waiter was pretty bad.  Gave bad recommendations on food and wine and actually his English was not fantastic, I think he was new.  We loved the space and wanted to love the food, but were not overwhelmed.  I thought for the prices (meal ended up being 170 pounds for 2 starters, 1 duck dish and two vegetables, 4 drinks) it was not worth it at all.  If you want to spend that kind of money in London you can get an exceptional meal elsewhere.

sOC7G2dQnufRNiZur9VFoA.text: We had the 3 courses and a cocktail for £38 deal. All three dishes were worth the money and the cocktails are great there too. The decor is dimly lit and has a nice relaxed vibe. The service is spectacular, I would definitely go back.

tC1YEOziosBHjHGDpopZbQ.text: A party of 6 of us dined here for a dim sum brunch one brisk January Sunday afternoon.  This restaurant is located in the basement of a non-descript building without any signs at the entrance. I suppose when you have a one Michelin star, you don't really need to advertise much.The atmosphere in this place was very romantic, dim and warm. I knew immediately upon absorbing the decor that this was an elegant fine dining establishment. The staff members of this restaurant were very well trained. They were friendly, warm, welcoming and quite knowledgeable about the menu items. They made me feel like a valued patron of their establishment and it was very nice.The food and drinks we ordered were served in a timely manner and without a doubt, quite delicious. While I recognize the basics of each dim sum dish, every item was "kicked up a notch". These were no traditional dim sum dishes, but more of a nuevo version.  Don't come here to expect the Hong Kong cart service dim sum experience. Instead, be ready for a totally new dining experience. If you've never visited Hakkasan, I do highly recommend trying this place at least once for a Sunday brunch and return for a dinner service if you like it.

33FN3XGQIrRpS9zi44HWXQ.text: This is one of my favorite restaurants in London. I have to admit I like the atmosphere and vibe of the Hanway Place better - this one feels like it is lacking in decoration and the tables are really close together. On the other hand, you aren't walking on cobblestones and ruining your shoes to get to the door and it is easier to get to this location. Pros:-The service is the same as the original-Food quality is the same as the original and has always been amazing-Cocktails are always yummy-If you or your friends are vegetarian it has a very wide selectionFavorite Dishes:-Crispy Duck Salad-Stir-fry black pepper vegetarian chicken with sugar snap-Tofu, aubergine and Japanese mushroom claypot

_VGO0DcVPZjxpuxrkETPDA.text: Get to the Chase:I haven't had the chance to go to the NY one as of yet, but the following applies to LondonPros:1) If you're in London, you must try this umptious gumptious good restaurant! If you ever doubted that Chinese food could be ungreasy, fancy, and absolutely delicious without feeling oil clogged throat glands then you will be AMAZED and WOWed by this fab establishment!2) I'd say almost anything is worth it on the menu, but highly recommend: Szechuan mabo tofu with minced Welsh black beef, or the Pan-fried Wagyu beef in spicy Szechuan sauce, ooor Stir-fry Australian lobster in spicy black bean sauce! NOMMERS to the max!3) Fantastic ambience! The venue is soo swanky, it's like a VIP Vegas club meets gastronomy wow-palooza!4) Cocktails are also FANTASTISH! The Hakka - Belvedere vodka, Akashi-tai sake, lychee juice, lime, coconut and passion fruitCons:1) Uhh yea did you see that price? Duuuuuuurrrr you'll be missing a kidney, lunch and any other spare organs to pay off the price2) Portions aren't spectacularly filling

sEpVuH_LQ8BMW1ZlsZCOCQ.text: One of the top 3 meals in my life! I am amazed how can someone not give this place 5-stars...The decor is sleek,sexy and tasteful...makes you feel you're in a place everyone wants to beThe dishes were amazing. The honey glazed sea bass was heaven...didn't know fish can melt in your mouth like that...worth every penny!The crispy duck salad also a must! A fresh, crunchy blend of vegetables and succulent crispy duck It's been 4 months and I still feel the wonderful taste memory in my mouth...Can't wait to go again...

LJ0f9k0jpH6Cs5QmExucIw.text: It is the best dim sum I ever had. I'm not a connoisseur, but their duck and truffle dim sum taste is as colourful as an impressionist painting. I would never think of dim sum the same again. My friend loved the scallop and caviar dim sum - I thought it was good - but not as good as duck ones.For mains we had king prawn with what seemed to be a un-popped corn in sweetish dark sauce - delicious. Venison stir fry was a bit of a disappointment. Honestly, I don't think I'm a fan of red meat unless it comes in a steak and bloody.The rice crispy dessert (praline ball wrapped in milk chocolate and rice crispies) was very good - though I'd thought that putting dark chocolate instead of milk chocolate would have been better and less sweet. I don't like desserts that are too sweet.As for atmosphere - we sat downstairs - with the dimmed lights and background conversations around us. Though with quite a few people around and a birthday lunch nearby - it was still very moderate amount of noise. It was very pleasant.Service - very good. The waiter forgot to serve us our champagne - so we got it on the house when we asked after our bubbles.For two dim sum starters, two mains and one dessert - we spent £90 overall and left the restaurant feeling full.I would go back for the dim sum alone.

oBDzSNkXIWPzvLMqBa2OVA.text: There are very few life changing meals you'll have in one lifetime...and that's the truth, though a sad one. Hakkasan was a life changing meal that we had in London. I've been to 'gourmet' or 'high end' Asian before. From living in NYC and Chicago, I've spent too much of my money on overpriced Asian food. However this place lived up to the billing. From the lettuce wraps, to the pork belly, to the black truffle duck. - each dish was cooked to perfection with flavor combinations that I had just never tasted before. This is not one of those 'the ingredients speak for themselves' type of restaurants. I have no doubt that they are using top notch ingredients in their kitchen, but there is a bit of genius to what they are doing back there. I can't say much more then this, but if you're looking for a high end meal for a special night, this is one of the truly amazing restaurants I've been to.

KUAU1kAQxYe5TZeAwN07JQ.text: Super busy and quite noisy.  We were crammed in-between other diners at a high top table.  It took awhile to get service.  Once we placed our order our food came out quickly.  The dim sum platter was good but not the best we've ever had.  The royal sweet corn soup was very good.  Silver cod was flaky and delicious.  Wagyu beef was tender and all seasoned.I couldn't give it 5 stars because although it was good, it wasn't the best meal I have had and the seating was awful.

NKUlZhvRsDt6jT-vEnylzw.text: As fast as I hear "Asian fusion" I immediately think of the word - disaster. But Hakkasan really proved me wrong, this is one of the coolest restaurants I went to when visiting London. The restaurant is located in a weird alley away from the busy streets of London and it was a bit difficult walking there. Hakkasan is located in a basement, and while going down in the dark, but smartly lit, restaurant you instantly see how fancy everything is. It surely something that you will have to see for yourself.All the waiters/waitresses were all dressed up neatly and acted very professional. We had a wonderful waiter that helped us throughout the whole meal which was great.Last but not least, the food was really good and I would recommend trying their asian fusion dumplings. For desert I had some port wine, that was recommended by the waiter, which went perfect with a set of truffles. The whole experience was excellent, I would definitely visit Hakkasan again.

F3wBKmk95bbMdke6dqRTJg.text: I am sorry to express but I still cannot believe this restaurant is ranked 60th in The World 100 Best Restaurants Awards in 2011...theworlds50best.com/awar…

x5io9YupbkK_mmUcT1EyuQ.text: I used to really like Yauatcha and thought it was one of the few restaurants that managed to execute authentic cantonese dim sum in London.  Naturally I am curious about its more famous sister restaurant and finally went there for lunch with a friend.  FOOD:Every dish was well executed. We ordered a few dishes to share: dim sum platter, lamb salad, mui choi (pickled vegetables) & char siu (bbq pork) cheung fun, crispy prawn and shrimp roe with noodles  and the banana caramel souffle.  We liked everything - the dim sum were authentic and I really enjoyed the lamb salad, which uses pickled chinese vegetables and I thought that was quite innovative. Overall, very satisfied with the quality of the food.SERVICE: When it comes to service, I have high expectations considering the price point and the fact that the restaurant has been awarded Michelin stars.  To be fair, everything was great until we were served the wrong dish.  I ordered the crispy prawn and shrimp roe with noodles but our waitress had mistakenly thought we were ordering the crispy prawn (no noodles).  When we told her about the mistake, her response was simply that there was no such dish.  Eventually I had to flip open the menu, turn to the relevant page and point the dish out to her.  She did serve us the correct dish but we both felt that she was giving us an attitude from that point onwards. Perhaps she was just having a bad day.  To be fair, everyone else was friendly, attentive and helpful but it did leave me wondering if sub par service was a common theme across Hakkasan and Yauatcha.

kQn0VG3s3MTW_prwlL_-ew.text: How does a simple bloke from North America get a table at short notice at an establishment frequented by celebs, socialites, and monied elites? I have my ways, lol.The restaurant was dimly lit, with dark colored furniture and walls.  Surprisingly,  the noise level was quite high for such a prominent restaurant.  I could hardly hear my dining mates.I primed my palate with the Hakkatini, a beverage loaded with L'Orange Grey Goose, Campari, and  Grand Marnier.  The delicious citrus flavor disguises the deceptively large amount of alcohol in this drink.Though we ordered an assortment of a la carte items, I'll focus on my favorite dish- the dim sum platter.  It consisted of the scallop shumai, har gau, prawn chive dumpling, and shimeji dumpling.  The steamed items were so light and flavorful that I could have eaten two orders.The service was a tad slow, but once at our table the staff were very attentive and presented the dishes well.

guBno1K4qhg8HVPHLt0Wxw.text: My understanding was that the original Hakkasan is a Michelin star restaurant.  We went to Hakkasan Mayfair and I was immediately struck by how big the venue is.  The décor is very trendy with a dramatic dimly lit stone entrance.  The entrance is striking but the coat room logistics needs some work.  We had four starters, four dishes and two rices to share between four of us.  The portions were almost spot on but we needed a bit more rice.  The dishes that really stood for me were the crispy duck salad (amazing!), the champagne and honey cod and the black pepper rib-eye.  The dim sum platter to start was nice but it wasn't drastically better than what you'd get at a good dim sum house.  Overall the food was great, the service was good but you paid for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

kmhZYxHS95BMjFOp_D3ZUg.text: Incredible ambiance, friendly service, good value just an amazing experience now I know why it received a Michelin star

tfm3XqHe4CMovav2ZYYQsQ.text: We took up the excellent value £35 set lunch menu.. The dumplings were beyond dreamy, and the cherry tomato bloody Mary was perfect Sunday fare.

N5mNnU9vG387-A7YIAO3sQ.text: My mom and I went to this wonderful restaurant thanks to all the good reviews.The food was amazing (especially the starters, such as dim sum and spring rolls).The only thing that bothered us was the dim light and overall mysterious environment.Great place, I would come back again as soon as possible.

UtzVe2sn60iRYvesk-s59g.text: Hakkasan London- It definitely stands out amongst all the Chinese restaurants in all the western cities (ok maybe not in LA or Vancouver). I see a little fusion in the dishes but it makes it even better. It's definitely not the best in the world but it's by far the best in London, well I would say, in Europe. The vibe is really up-scale and it's really not easy to find good, upscale, Chinese restaurants in London. The service was top notch and the guests all look really good and mostly local...If you've been to Hakkasan in NYC I would say that the one is London is so much better...  dim sum & sea bass = must try

CJLcGFVqrPDvuQdMxXwaOQ.text: One of the best meals I had in London. I would highly recommend it! Everything I had on the menu was excellent and I don't think you can go wrong. The best way to go is to order a couple things off the menu and share so you can try a few items. This is definitely a "scene" filled with some of the trendiest  and best dressed Londoners/tourists. Pricey but great service and totally worth it!

lQCTM3CpbUU6VWZMe3WxCA.text: Client brought me here for an early dinner, I opted for the dimsum platter as I never get good dimsum in Miami.  Flavorful and delicious!  Chinese food in London is a bit better than the 'westernized' Chinese food in the US.  So, I am adding this to my list of go-to restaurants in London.

VfnDwe3VeOsDqbKrT4wJrw.text: This place is absolutely as good as it gets.  If I could take one star off for anything, it would be that I do not live anywhere near London, and instead one should be located in Alamo Square;) There are two restaurants in London, went to both, both amazing.  Put it this way, spend four nights in London and went here three times. (further disclaimer, I only found out about this place on the second night). Its so funny too, how to get to one of the locations you go through this small, narrow cobblestoney street.  So small in fact the taxi prefers to let you out a few roads over.  And then you open the door to modern, and sophisticated.   If you stay too long and drink too much its entirely possible you will forget where you are.It is chic...think LA, think Miami, think NY...its dark, huge, trendy and absolutely sexy.  The food is incredible.  It looks as good as the people who are dining.  It is chinese food, and with my lack of chinese reviews we know this is not my go to cuisine...not because I don't like it, but because it does not like me, yet this food I could eat everyday.  What is even more ridiculous, is that each time we ended up here after having dinner elsewhere but staying up too late we needed second dinner.  You can't go wrong with the dim sum and you should go with someone who is open to sharing.  Try any of the cocktails.  The bar is probably the longest I've ever seen.  The servers friendly.  And its packed until 1am.  Oooh, and the bathroom as really good smelling soap! Seriously, as good as it gets.

5o1sbxGyuMz3BBvagoP45Q.text: Disappointing all around.Pre Fixe Reservations last night at 7pm.  Got there a little early.  By the time we sat, it was 7, asked if we could get the pre fixe - answer was no, had to be ordered before 7pm.  Really?Tasting MenuWanted a tasting menu - told minimum 3 persons because it was a lot of food.  Well, as you charge per person, why can't you as the restaurant make the correct amount of food for 2 persons?If you really just want £195 for the tasting menu, just say so instead of writing £65 per person, minimum 3.  Write that it's £195 for up to 3 persons.  What jackasses.  A michellin star restaurant and you can't make the appropriate portion size for number of people?And that means for all of you in groups of 4 thinking about a tasting menu - they probably will charge you for 4 persons, but bring you the same portion size they would have for 3 persons, since they can't seem to make different portions of foodFoodOverall, the meal was too oily, and I had a difficult time eating it.  We had the dim sum platter - it's pretty, but at £15, nothing special.  I'm not sure how everyone says Hakkasan kicks it up a notch, it's platted pretty, but flavors are oily and not that different.  I definitely did not taste any of the bold and intense flavors others seem to credit this restaurant with.We had the senpai chicken (chicken cooked really well), pepper rib-eye (tasteless), and the morning glory (oily and heavy), and the vegetarian vermicelli (once again, oily).Hidden ChargesAfter we ordered, the waitress asked if we wanted rice, seafood vermicelli, egg noodles, or vegetable vermicelli.  We ordered the vegetable vermicelli - which ended up being £10.  I think for something that pricey, it should have been on the menu.  I don't even want to know what the price of the seafood vermicelli would have been.DessertWe had the java things - which was described as an ice cream ferrero roche.  It was semi cold ice cream with a rice krispy shell.  I'm not sure what part of that made the chef think it was a good idea,  And it looked like a snail that went for a walk and left it's slime everywhere.

6dyGFPTx2ChPebdfOcz2CA.text: Was here during the Chinese New Year, gotta say I loved it!! Ordered the dim sum dishes and a crab, particularly loved the dim sum. Very delicately made. The desserts were also lovely!

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

n76FEF-3xUvUZswGP1y0BQ.text: We went there for Lunch. Firstly let me start with the interior & the size of the place, being a fine dinning restaurant in Mayfair with such a good reputation a lot was expected. The place was a bit depressing with its gloomy interior & its small space but other than that as in -food wise- it was perfect.We had the very well-known duck salad & it was AMAAZING with a very unique sour-sweet taste along with the duck i would give it 10/10.Then we had Sesame Prawn Toast , it was good & the taste was very new & interesting , i would give it 7/10.Then we had also the very recommended-Ribeyes beef -medium cooked- was AMAAZING & just perfect , i would give it 10/10 if you had it with their house noodle.For the drinks we had some non-alcoholic cocktails which were great, in particular the one that has berries & strawberriesFor the dessert we had the so-called famous chocolate bomb, which looked so unbelievably yummy & irresistible from the outside but flavour wise it wasn't much , as the rice crisps had overwhelmed the flavour along with the very dark sweetless chocolate sauce. It was too much for us. I would give it 5/10 -flavour wise- . The waiters were very helpful with very good recommendations, we just hoped we chose what they recommended for dessert. Other than that i would give the whole experience 9/10.Cheers!

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

QLVOiI2E5Zb5sLFr7QzLpA.text: Used to be very good, now its still good but not quite the same. Flavours in some of the dishes have been a bit of a let down

FcNljaSPWUqxPJviztWoCA.text: I was very excited to try this place as I've heard so much about it. The food is good, but not the best Chinese food I've had. I had a duck dish (don't remember exactly) - it was very tasty!

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Didn't have a close up photo of the food. Looks very nice and taste good

_Z1L28IDGG55lYGNGD133w.text: Crispy duck salad with the Roxanich wine from Croatia = Bliss.Grilled Wagyu comes in slices and seems more steamed than grilled but tasted good, of course.Mocca dessert was really nice.

Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Mocca dessert.

m-mYI1t0MDUU9l-1H_kWig.text: A very average experience.  In spite of all the fuss, I find the food to be very average, great service but sitting in a basement for this average quality food is not my idea of a great meal.  Just because the prices are high, staff is nicely dressed and they make all the fuss, it just does not meet the standards that you achieve by providing good quality food above ground.We tried the dims platter - non-veg option is marginally better than the veg option (avoid it)... Chicken in the claypot is full of fat and not well cooked, other main veg and non veg dishes are similar, baby broccoli, lamb... Soup is good but again avoid the vegetarian option... The only thing I really liked on the menu was their Hakka noodles.

jxuHzFT7tHDAB2fdOWo3bw.text: THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!! YES its a bit pricey but it's definitely worth the money. Their dumplings were delicious and perfectly made, they give you a selection of interesting sauces tooTry the sea bass - it melts in your mouth I need to check out their other locations in NYC and Miami (thanks Kanye for the rec)

f8T_V4J-nPupxnDNPNx2hA.text: The greeting on arrival,  friendly and polite. The the decor and atmosphere was spot on. It was not over the top. Drinks and cocktails had added quality and the FOOD was amazing, I would recommend it. As Arnold Schwarzenegger said "I'll be back"

JNZwkvFXD36jrKEbI8xbtg.text: Had dinner here with a small group of friends. We probably ordered too much! We had so many dishesSome stand out dishes include:Jasmine tea smoked ribs - flesh is sweet, soft and falls off the boneSweet and sour pork - definitely one of the best in LondonMui choi glutinous rice - A very Asian dish. I very much enjoyed the chewiness of the rice.The weaker dishes were actually those that have been "fancied" up. A prime example is the roast duck with black truffle. Not nearly as good as plain roast duck you can find in other Cantonese restaurantsin London. You'll find quite a few such dishes I believe were created for customers looking to blow more cash on their meal. A bowl of hot and sour soup for more than £12 is unreasonableThe simple dishes here are done very well, however I dont think I would bother with anything with truffle or caviar when I come back

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Loved the sweet and sour pork!
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Ordered too much!

m5tD3BsNaw1WDPwWQOtwrw.text: MEH, wouldn't bother.The sweet-chilli dip was the saving grace to 3 out of 4 dishes we ordered. Without it, we were simply eating rather bland food. Agree with previous reviewer when she says, "The weaker dishes were actually those that have been "fancied" up".Fun wine list and nice to have red served at a good temperature.Service a bit sloppy. Requested table that we were assured was "reserved for another diner" when we arrived, and we had a choice between 2 tables upstairs facing service areas, or one in the basement area. Bit of a fight to get waiter/waitress attention.Wouldn't eat here or at its sister restaurants again.

5I2_7jdLu0apNcn_u304LQ.text: What a surprise!   Our cabby recommended this spot after the theater and it was fantastic.

FofQrv2OC4mmWwPge6OOWQ.text: Hakkasan may have lost some of its cache in recent years, as the group has expanded globally and trendier venues like Chiltern Firehouse & Berners Tavern have muscled in on their turf, but I still love it.You are guaranteed good food, good cocktails and a great atmosphere. It is undoubtedly expensive, but you are guaranteed to have a lot of fun here whether it's for a special occasion like a birthday/anniversary or a larger group dinner with friends. My girlfriend has chosen this for her birthday two out of the last 3 years. (Sushi Samba wedged in between).Stand out dishes are the Dim Sum platters, the champagne cod, the beef and merlot stir fry. The steamed turbot and chicken satay are also favourites. For dessert, the Jivara bomb is the must try dish. Cocktail wise, the smoky negroni is my staple and they make a great old fashioned.Budget for about £100-£125 a head for starters, mains, dessert & wine.

M0TtnlpozKZRIvUA2O17Rw.text: My the bartenders were well versed and did a wonderful job picking out drinks for us based upon our preferences. The service was amazing and as always the food was delicious. I've been to Hakkasan in Las Vegas, Los Angeles and London and I am equally impressed between them all!

oRSyCtQ5ZkVJ81yrFe98Mw.text: Really fabulous place - great food, cool vibe,and good service. Easy to miss it as there is no sign out front - just a bouncer standing by the front door. I make it a regular stop any time I am in London

4to9a-T1gg6M5o47ICliMg.text: As a Michelin Star restaurant (the ONLY Chinese / Cantonese on Earth as of now), any seasoned dining vet would certainly have high expectations on both food AND service. So in turn, you should anticipate only the best. Right? FOOD: Dim Sum was great. Venison (tender without a game taste), and the lobster rolls ( outer crust resembling frosted mini wheats without the frost) were a hit! As for the rest of the dim sum items, they were flawless ( ie,  beef brisket in another dish was lean and tender). I was told prior to my arrival at this restaurant, that some of the best restaurants in London are tucked away in random dark discreet alley ways. This is true after this experience ( I've posted some pics of the alley ways and stairs which lead to this posh dining place). Yes, it is a hidden gem.SERVICE:My pet peeve for giving any fine dining establishment a perfect 5 star restaurant comes with exceptional / attentive service. This is essential. I ate during late lunch hours around 2pm, so it was not busy at all. Many surrounding tables were vacant which in turn should allow servers to give full attention to the diners. The only issue I encountered was their attentiveness. For example, overall service was perfect until my glass of water went dry and I was still in the middle of my meal. The restaurant wasn't busy so I expected a prompt refill. Several minutes had passed as I waited... and waited.  I needed to grab the attention of our waitress. Service and meal must go hand-in-hand. SUMMARY: Definitely a 5 star restaurant but service needed to be more on point.The bar, the cozy bench pillow seating, and hip modern asian flared ambience really set the tone. This restaurant truly deserves a 4 1/2 star rating. However due to yelps rating restrictions of giving whole stars instead of half stars, I would have to rate this place a 4. Definitely check this place out if you get the chance to visit London!

UQaqWn5g5puySxoXdYkBgA.text: Went here for my birthday! Very cool atmosphere! I ordered a 'ice cream rice ball' dish for my dessert... it was not that great! So get something else for dessert but the food (especially the curry) is to die for!

NzhZnkcnW69mg2ZR2Uq3vg.text: Hakkasan is the kind of place one goes to see and be seen. And it serves its purpose exceptionally well. Sultry lighting, tightly-packed open dining areas, and a location in one of London's meccas for the well-to-do create a conflux of factors that encourage socialite (and wannabe) congregation.Attractive serving girls, (attempted) flair bar tending (isn't free-pouring not the done thing in the UK?), and beautiful copywriting of menu items enhance the vibe. If the conversations of the parties on either side of our table were any indication, this is more often than not a date night destination as well. For you heteros out there, guys take note: between the middle-of-the-road priced girly beverages and the natural aphrodisiacs in the food, your chances of scoring upon bringing a lady friend here may possibly skyrocket.*The £14 dim sum platter was unlike any dim sum I'd ever had before. Posh merely nicks the surface of just how fusion each steamed quasi-dumpling appeared and tasted. I highly recommend the sea bass with Szechuan chillies - just don't expect much heat. Even with a warning from our server about avoiding the spicy peppers, I barely felt a tingle on my tongue. And whilst the sauteed morningglories (cong xing cai) were perfectly ample and tender, you could probably get an equivalent dish at many eateries in Chinatown for a fraction of the cost.All in all, a fine enough experience. I'd just rather have the real thing... at a relative pittance of the expense of Hakkasan.------*Full disclosure: this is not something that's been personally tested. I'm drawing some broad conclusions based on overheard chats and visible body language.

Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Szechuan sea bass

jSgB71lsUgP5R1Bruo9xuQ.text: Our lovely friends invited us to Hakkasan to celebrate a birthday. We are vegetarians with strong aversions to mushrooms which is usually an extremely problematic experience when dining non-vegetarian fare. The host of the fete made sure to call and voila! The amazing chef at Hakkasan provided us a menu (via email) of non-mushroom vegetarian options that may be specially made for us with advanced notice. So, before we even got to Hakkasan, we were off to a great start as far as excellent customer service is concerned.PLEASE NOTE BEFORE READING AHEAD:The only *only* reason Hakkasan has not received a 100% perfect, handy-dandy review is because...gasp! Although they are extremely accommodating to vegetarian diners, their veggie-friendly dishes need a lot of work in terms of flavor. Other than that, another minor note: It is very hard to find this place as it has no signage. You have to spot a little red door and a very fancy and important staff member outside with a clipboard deciding who gets in. He or she has the omnipresence and power of Oz, apparently. Just a tidbit for ya'll.Hakkasan is super swanky. We arrived in our finest Friday night attire to be seated in an extremey spacious booth. The decor is unmatched - everything is gorgeous, spotless and the service is so fantastic you're not even allowed to THINK about pouring your water.  Yes, that's a bonafide fact. They take care of everything for you.We ordered cocktails (lychee martinis, anyone?) and starters. Everything was served quickly. Everything we ordered was masterfully placed into our dishes / bowls and we had the choice of chopstix (or not). Everything we ate was extremely fresh (down to the salmon our friends enjoyed) and we had no complaints. Food came faster than we can eat and our cocktails kept flowing - no problems there. It was an evening to remember with a rather terrifying price tag but all worth it. Not sure I would come there again because of the lack of tasty options but I'd definitely recommend it to meat-loving (or seafood obsessing) diners. It's a beautiful place and everyone should be so lucky as to experience it. Magnifique!

t5scYv2GIAAa7_iZmhkIWw.text: I was extremely disappointed with everything that I ordered here. The "all flash and no bang" principle applies here. The vibe is excellent. The service is excellent. The decor is excellent. This is where it ends. I will admit that I am spoiled because my office is in the heart of Chinatown in San Francisco however my expectations of Hakkasan were high. The food was "marginal" at best. I spent $135.00 (US) just on me. I would not go back because the food was unspectacular.

629Vi007dL4XlgzSpZMNHw.text: Had high expectations going in, but was somewhat disappointed. Food was average at best and tasted more like a chain restaurant, rather than one which has been awarded a Michelin Star. We had the vegetarian corn soup, the grilled Shanghai dumplings, salt and pepper squid, stir-fry vegetable lettuce wraps, XO Scallops Stuffed Zucchini, and the stir-fry black pepper rib eye beef with merlot. The notable items were the beef and the squid, everything else was very average or below average. Had the rhubarb margarita which was decent; it was advertised as spicy by our waiter, but it was more sweet than spicy. Had a very bland dirty martini as well. All in all, not a bad meal, but did not nearly meet any expectations, especially in a city with so many great options.

FrvsWMs0RPu3nNsqs_r7qA.text: I had high expectations for this restaurant due to the price range and how exclusive they were when I made the reservation. We came here for a corporate dinner. I made reservations ahead of time and I was told that we would need to pre-select a fixed menu for 68 pounds per person for private dining. I agreed and signed an agreement that we will show up or we would be subject to a 20% charge. We get to the restaurant and it is noisy and very crowded. We did NOT get a private dining space, rather we were seated in the basement with the louder crowd. It took them 20 minutes to greet us with water and waited another 20 to get our cocktails. I spoke to the waiter in charge and asked her if we could order things a la carte besides the fixed menu that was given to us, she answered with such a rude tone and told me repeatedly that we had chosen the pre fixed menu and we needed to spend at the minimum of 68 pounds per person. I assured her that we will go well over the minimum and to just take whatever my colleagues ordered. I get back to the table and they start bringing out appetizers (dim sum platters). The dumplings were good and they gave out generous portions for everyone to have enough. However, we were still sitting there waiting for our alcoholic beverages to be served. My colleague finally asked for the manager, and until then did they expedite their service. The pre fixed menu came with a TON of food. I thought we each get to choose from the selection, but they brought out everything from the list and served it family style. It was very filling, some dishes were very oily but for the most part it was good. I would rate this place 3 stars partially because of the food quality but mostly due to their service. It is a very upscale and expensive venue and the experience and service should parallel the profile they ought to maintain. The location is great and is in central London but the staff could be a bit more friendlier and accommodating especially for out of country individuals who look for a great dining experience.

UGPU6PjKfGNsZejdZhgc2w.text: The infamous Hakassan  lives up to its expectation!!!As a "foodian" and restaurant lover, I've been itching to go to Hakassan for ages. Truthfully, my desire to go was more based on my restaurant checklist combined with my inquisition with the whole hype with Hakassan so I was so excited when my husband told me he had booked a table for my birthday. I am happy to report it definitely lives up to expectations. Although the portions are tiny, it is definitely quality over quantity with excellent service and amazing buzzing atmosphere, especially as it was a Tuesday night. For a special occasion or night out I highly recommend it and the location is added bonus.

ypax_jgjW5eSPEPLe5CPHw.text: Love the vibe of the place! Definitely a dress to impress type of crowd. Some friends and I went for dinner before going out. We ordered a variety of plates (portions are small). The service was good. The only thing was they bought out the plates one by one instead of all together.Will be back on my next trip!

9p_QpQv2Ko5aqxbt3hiODQ.text: A good restaurant but don't go on a Sunday!Half the dishes have run out.If you call ahead to find out if they have it or not Cornelia and Co. (the front desk tam) are simply not interested to answer. Probably because they don't serve half the menu on a sunday. I explained to Cornelia that every time I go on a sunday this happens and she had plenty of opportunity to correct me but she didn't. She kept repeating disinterestedly "food is subject to availability" !!!!Never experienced that before at any , let alone, michelin restaurant .One stand out dish which is also one of the signatures at Mayfair that they ALWAYS run out of on Sundays is the dim sum supreme...but they should make this information available on the phone at least if you take the time to call and enquire about it .

dYgMy27tMelH30BmClhgBw.text: I have a very good friend who, when he comes to visit, we choose a special bookmarked place to dine at. This time it was Hakkasan Mayfair. And, as always with my mega-bookmarks, I had high hopes.First things first, this place is not cheap. It is affordable, but you could literally spend as much as you like (I'm looking at you 'Peking duck with royal beluga caviar'...) We ordered the lowest price set/tasting menu which was around £38 a person for 4 small dim sum, a small main/rice portion and a little dessert each. After adding in an extra couple of starters at £17 a pop, and some plain noodles at £10, it's starting to look pretty pricey. The food was delicious, it must be said. Every bite was great and full of flavour; well seasoned and not at all greasy. None of it blew my mind though. It was 'good' Chinese, probably one of the best, but I'm not sure how they can charge 5x the price of anywhere else for most of the dishes.The atmosphere was a little stifling. The (many many) staff were rather offish and frowny. We walked in all smiles and immediately felt like we were going to be put on the naughty step for being too cheerful. Also, thanks, but I don't need to be followed into the loo, I promise not to steal your Aesop soap.It's obviously a very classy restaurant, with embroidered leather seating, dimmed lighting and black gloss counters. It felt VERY dark though, more like a cocktail bar than a restaurant. Which is where I leave my final thought (Jerry Springer style). Hakkasan does incredible INCREDIBLE cocktails. Amazing. We had three each (at £12.50 a pop), and they were all flawless. I would happily go here just for the drinks. If you're not paying, go here for the food, if you are, just go for the drinks.

sBUf5jOIPBeoJpfYJTf2Ng.text: Me and my husband fav fusion Chinese restaurant. The food is not too salty, everything is so fresh, drinks are very good too. Lots of space in the restaurant, stuffs are very friendly as well. Def going back again!

M3cV-IwW1xkpLxbzBT5kAw.text: Have been to here twice（for dinner），Went for lunch today. I had quite good experience last two times so I decided to give it a third visit.When I felt that I can't finish all the food （they came quite large）the waitress told me they didn't do takeaway. I was very surprised and realised I spent 74 pounds for wasting these food？！If you don't do takeaway，then remind me the amount of food at first！The waitress didn't say anything about the food amount when taking the order（although she knew there was only one person）. By the way，dim sum shouldn't come that big！The service was poor as well. The lady downstairs  who served me made me feel not welcomed.Overall not good experience and kind of ruined my good mood for Christmas. Due to the poor experience today，I wouldn't go Hakassan anymore.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Dim sum that is bigger than it should be

PD8-ZPBVvmI_SWvbuiysag.text: Best overall dining experience we had in London. We did a shared plate dinner, which seems to be the thing there. The dim sum platter was tasty and varied, and it was easy for 4 to share (two pieces each of 4 items). If you like somewhat spicy dishes the spicy venison stir fry added an interesting flavor the otherwise standard Asian fare. The black truffle roast duck was simply incredible, and the stir fry lobster in white peppercorn sauce rounded out the meal. The lobster dish was very tasty, but it didn't have enough of a lobster flavor to really mandate a lobster price. You could have told me it was chicken in white peppercorn sauce and I would have believed it. But good. Highly recommend. Solid service, great atmosphere, excellent food.

ivP4cGDIXptKlTUgPAG8-w.text: I visited for a work lunch and was suitably impressed.The prices can be eye-watering. This being a work/client lunch, we'd pre-arranged to have the £118 set lunch menu. This consisted of lots of delicacy meats including lobster, sea bass and wagyu beef. Suffice to say this was cooked and presented in a sharing manner. Being the most expensive meal I've ever eaten did it deliver? Yes on all counts.The food itself was stunning. It was tasty, well portioned considering the sharing but I could have done with an extra piece of some of the dim sum they served early in the meal. The sea bass was the best dish by group consensus, it was lovely and flaky. Each pieces just melting in your mouth. The duck was a very close second, but didn't surprise like the seabags.Decor just amazing. The place looked the part and service was impeccable too as you'd expect at this high end restaurant. I normally don't like stuffy places but this was anything but. Nice friendly professional staff were attentive and on hand.In all, would I spend this much on my own dime? Most likely not, but about half that is certainly possible given how the set menus scale. The only reason our menu was so expensive were the meats which were all some of the most expensive premium meats in non-typical dishes. E.g. prawns replaced with scollop. Dishes were finished in expensive truffle etc...It's not a place to visit often, but if you're looking to impress then this place is certainly one to have in the address book.

Dpag21vmh5P3X-jEy9BP_w.text: Very classy, top of the range cuisine and atmosphere was very lively. Good place to take loved one.

GpvA014pcsKokgRRccdpyA.text: When u first entered Hakkasan, u might think it's a nightclub, but in fact is a chinese restaurant. There are two guys standing at the front door, for a second I thought they were bouncers.  There are like 8-10 staffs standing at the reception with nothing to do, my first impression is that this place is overstaffed.  Although this place is chic and trendy, but fortunately they cook Chinese food the traditional way, just adding a little twist.  Food in general tastes pretty good.Recommend dish: dim sum platter, mapo tofu, beef with black pepper sauce, roasted duck, and the morning glory with chilli sauce. Their cocktails were great as well, we had the Kowloon cooler, which was wonderful.The server was not the welcoming kind and warned us saying we can only take pictures of ourselves and on food we've ordered.  She told me that there were restaurant police around to check on people taking unauthorised picture of the restaurant.  I found it hilarious and stupid.

amOBDjxk50tNpUfiKXvyUA.text: Undoubtedly one of my favourite restaurants. First came here for a work dinner and we all ordered one of their signature menu - starter, main, dessert.. Amazing. Since then, i've been recommending this place to anyone who's looking for something a little more special.  Oh! Their cocktails - I'd recommend 'The Hakka';) everytime

h-tQMCRhPbAU-5niELmj3w.text: Great, speedy service. Excellent food all round. Decent price given the quality and location.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Crispy salt and pepper squid.

3SCK4E10FmabLhMvPUOlNg.text: This is a chain restaurant and each one, to their credit, is actually different. The one in Istanbul is the bomb!  One in San Francisco makes killer drinks and serves to the FiDo crowd given its location.Mayfair Hakkasan:  you go for the atmosphere.The dim lighting, the small seemingly irregular spaces, all add to one's happy enjoyment.I have never left Hakkasan Mayfair sober.Why only 3 stars? Food is over priced for what it is and service is glacial.

c9XJTIR4xnRg7eVebGjWHA.text: Absolutely fantastic upscale Chinese cuisine - of course, as you'd expect from a Michelin-starred restaurant. Many traditional authentic dishes are present, along with some more innovative offerings that really show the creativity and care that went into the menu. Execution and presentation were both flawless - every dish we tried was delicious. Service is attentive and professional, yet not intrusive at all. Truly a top-notch dining experience; it managed to outshine both the New York and SF locations that I've also tried. Hakkasan also blows competitor Hutong out of the water, both in terms of food quality and service.

b3LHeCscsM5MLnXRESwRGw.text: Great food and great service. We had the taste of hakassan menu - dim sum platter, beef, sea bass and selection of desert. I would definitely recommend this restaurant!

IXyVpTR_3uS5e-m8nKn6hA.text: Absolutely amazing food, attentive and nice service (so unusual for England) and an ambiance matching the nicest places I've been to in Miami or NYC.A decent dinner for 2 with some drinks will run about £110 or so but I found it to be well worth it. Dim Sum and Dumplings were great, as well as the Sea Bass.Will definitely return!

nzDiAU2OiHmzMcACLE_DqA.text: Been to this branch a few times for dinner, but never for lunch!!Yesterday was my first lunch sitting, booked it last minute in the morning and they were so helpful with the times we could come in for. Booked the table for 1pm, we arrived early, so we sat and ordered drinks. Opted for Taste of Hakkasan Menu £38 plus 1 cocktail and what a bargain, as the A La Carte menu prices will knock you off for 6!!! (Leave the A La Carte for date night ;))I opted for the Lychee Martini as I have had the Hakka a few times (my ultimate fave) but was time for a change, i loved the lychee martini with addition of rose and orange bitter - not too strong and not too sweet! Perfect combination (must try!)They give you 1 option to pick from the vast selection on offer, I opted for the Dim sum selection which consisted of a scallop, white crab and prawn, and crunchy prawn. Because I do not eat venison, they substituted it for a prawn toast. I loved the scallop dumpling, it was my first time trying the shellfish, it was cooked to perfection!!!! Soft and juicy, the crunchy prawn is good too, and the accompanying chilli sauce is fabb!!!! A little kick is needed, the salad on the side is yum too, its slightly bitter and tangy, but goes really well with the dumplings.For mains I went for Spicy Prawn with Lily Bulb and Almonds, mains come with rice and a side dish of asparagus! Before i tucked in, I just looked at how well it was presented, definitely instagram worthy, drooling. Looked amazing, and it certainly did not disappoint!! The flavours of the sauce was ahmayzing, that tang and zing from the limes and lemongrass, the texture of the lily bulb worked well, although I couldn't really see any almonds, but nonetheless the prawns were spicy - but not too much that it would leave you gulping gallons of water. Just the right amount of spice in it, the rice was nice and sticky and the asparagus cooked to perfection, cause you know sometimes it can be overcooked! I loved it all and i cleaned every last bit of sauce and prawns! It is a lot of food for 1, but if you are hungry like me, you will definitely finish it off!! My friends as they are veggies opted for the veggie chicken, which tasted a tad weird, was so rubbery and chewy, like you know when chicken is undercooked. Weird texture too, so all you veggies, I do not recommend this one for you, my friends liked it, but wouldn't order it again and they didn't finish it either!Now the best part of this meal was dessert, as I have had the classic Apple Tatin there, I went for the Jivara Bomb - milk chocolate, hazelnut praline and rice krispies. I know I was a bit shocked to see it covered in rice krispies but it actually works. When the waitress poured the chocolate sauce, it just oozed, there was no breaking it though, I think its one of those "show desserts" where nothing happens (boooohoooo hakkasan) there was no theatre!!!! But nonetheless once you manage to break it in half, you have the hazelnut praline parfait inside, hints of popping candy fizzing on your tongue and the tartness of raspberries on your tongue. A very innovative, playful dessert, simple, even though there was no drama, it was definitely tasty and something I'd order again. I love hakkasan, the service is always on point, they do accept last minute reservations for lunch. I love how big the restaurant is, one part is only open for lunch though, the long bar is so beautiful, adorned in red with the entwined HK sign!! Love love love.I highly recommend the lunch set menu, you won't be left disappointed, and definitely filling too!!

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Inside of the jivara bomb!
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Jivara bomb - milk chocolate, hazelnut praline and rice krispies (addition of popping candy) #colourblast
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Mains of prawns and veggie chicken #colourblast

VHR_cGVL8FoycLSTZJnsXA.text: This place serves what is undoubtedly the worst and most tasteless "Cantonese" food we have ever eaten. Forget even complaining about the prices, the food was just abominably and completely Bland And Tasteless.The spareribs we were served had been steamed to the texture of over cooked rice before being tossed on the grill for possibly a few moments, and then being drenched in the world's most Bland And Tasteless sauce.The duck stuffed egg rolls contained some Bland And Tasteless pulverized mixture that had clearly just come out of a blender. There truly was no hint of duck whatsoever, by sight or taste.This mixture of  "duck" guck was then wrapped in a very thick pastry, and deep fried long enough to add a quarter pound of grease to the weight of the roll. What's worse than a Bland And Tasteless duck guck egg roll? Try a Bland and Tasteless duck guck egg roll slogged down with a quarter pound of Grease!The Jasmine rice was unimaginably Bland and Tasteless and Overcooked with not a hint of Jasmine flavor. It's a Pure commodity rice from the bottom of the barrel that you would never buy for your home, and you would be better off bringing a container of cooked rice from a Tesco than eating this muck.There was no salt, pepper, soy sauce, hot mustard, chili sauce, duck sauce or any condiment whatsoever on the table (please ANYTHING to relieve the Bland And Tasteless!) and the wait staff seemed too hassled to bring any, not that it would have done any good anyway. Maybe why they don't bother bringing.

BhT9HftiomGhYzef5JmXTQ.text: This was my first time at Hakkasan and it lived up to the hype. We went on a Saturday night and it was quite busy as expected. Definitely recommend booking a few days ahead. The restaurant is quite big with lovely interiors and an intimate ambience though it can get quite loud. The food was absolutely delicious! Being a fan of Chinese food, I've had many meals at several places across the world but will definitely keep coming back to Hakkasan. There were 3 of us and we ordered the following:- supreme dim sum platter:  it was very well presented and there was a good balance of flavors. The chicken shumai with caviar was amazing!- Morel mushroom and vegetable spring rolls: tasty but nothing you wouldn't find at a good Chinese restaurant- Stir-fry Peking style duck: this was the best duck I've ever had and until yesterday I wasn't a fan of duck! If you don't eat duck then this might be the place to start at.- Stir-fry back pepper rib eye beef with Merlot: another absolutely delicious dish! - Hakka noodles: a dish most places take for granted but Hakkasan got it right.The cocktails were great as well! Overall an incredibly satisfying meal in every way.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

BK3iU4OottQi5TAX_XO-6A.text: When I first booked it I had no idea that this was a Michelin Star restaurant, I just wanted some Hakka cuisine. However, when looking at the menu after booking I learned it is a Michelin star restaurant. The ambiance is great and high class, so dress to impress! The service is great, and our server answered our queries about the food. I am vegetarian So I started with the veggie rumbling platter and it was PHENOMENAL. You get to eat 4 different types of really good dumplings. My main dish was black pepper vegetarian chicken which had a lot of good flavor. I highly recommend this restaurant. The ambiance is perfect for a date night.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

Je3pF8VyoHliwb1eU57d3w.text: I called Hakkasan ahead of a team dinner to inquire about vegan options for me (my team really wanted to eat here) and the restaurant emailed me a list of items that could be made vegan. When we arrived, it turned out that some of the items were no longer vegan, so my options were a little more limited. This restaurant had a great atmosphere, but I really thought my vegan options were basic and could have been more creative. For three of us, the bill was around $300 USD, which I found excessive especially since I was limited to a basic veg option. I'd only go here again for a company function but would not personally go back.

LRijz-IY8tjSOnHz1zhHLg.text: We're visiting London from LA and have been to the Hakkasan in Beverly Hills before it closed down.I've heard great things about Hakkasan (mostly regarding the Las Vegas location) from other (disclaimer: non-Asian) friends...and while we prefer authentic Cantonese/Taiwanese/Sichuan cuisines, I can appreciate the place for "Asian fusion" restaurants...every now and then, I'll even go to PF Changs cos it's easy (less intimidating/scary for friends wanting to stay in the "safer/what's familiar" zone of Chinese food) and it's clean and close by to where I'm meeting friends etc...and I know to temper my expectations from the PF Changs' meal ahead of time too.I'm giving this meal 3 instead of 2 stars because I've already been to Hakkasan Beverly Hills and already knew what we were getting into (food and price wise).We have no issues spending much much more on Chinese food (like $1000 USD and up for 2 for fancy Cantonese delicacies like shark's fin soup, bird's nest, abalone, spotted prawns, lobster, Alaskan king crab etc)...I really did want to like Hakkasan Mayfair in London, the decor is modern and very clean (one of my biggest issues with many "authentic ethnic" places) but the Supreme Dim Sum platter at £30 with 4 different items, 8 pieces total) tasted so tasteless and bland despite one having black truffle garnish and another with abalone inside...my fiancé actually told me he thought they all tasted pretty much the same if he was fed them all blindfolded!The Singaporean vermicelli was pretty tasteless and usually, that should be full of flavor and have some amount of spice to it...it looked the way it should (a bit yellow in color, usually cos of the curry powder/flavor) but completely bland...The soft shell crab small plate was crisp with light batter but we've also had just as good soft shell crabs at just about any other normal/homely Japanese restaurant in LA and even in Washington DC.The best thing was my Coconut Passion Fruit mocktail...def one of the best mocktails I've ever had (and we've had plenty from all levels of Michelin Star restaurants to local mom and pop eats around the world)...but I do tend to love sweet drinks and this was definitely very sweet but fresh and not artificial like many mocktails can be when they use just a mix of syrups and concentrated juice flavoring.I think if you do want an upscale Asian/Chinese but "safe/with some fusion options" place, go to Zhengs Chinese in Kensington.At Zhengs, every dish we ordered was tasty and well executed,  has modern spotlessly clean decor and from the crowd we saw dining there, it definitely has enough dishes to satisfy those wanting more of an Asian fusion taste.Ironically, I don't think I would say we'll never go to another Hakkasan, as there are times where you compromise and just go with the flow.It is definitely a popular enough place (like Nobu--which we do enjoy) that will come up amongst friends suggestions and the food hasn't seen terrible...but at the prices they charge (which is not really the issue for us since I know some people would never like a restaurant no matter how amazing it is just because they can't see any meal being worth over $100 usd or $200 usd per person)...Hakkasan would never be the "go to" place for us if it were just my fiancé and me selecting a restaurant to eat at...

n3Mx4bKiwqXStmWCdE1AXg.text: Except for the Dim Sum tasting starter which deserved 5+ stars, the remainder of the food and wine was utterly disappointing.The baby ribs for the second starter were decent, but the chefs had forgotten to remove the membrane at the bottom of the ribs - a rookie mistake for any baby rib pro!The Peking Duck style main course and the desserts were plain. We went with wine by the glass so the selection was limited. We ordered the Chardonnay for 15 pounds per glass. Unfortunately, the wine turned out to be grossly overpriced for a cheap bottle of Chardonnay that you can probably get at Tesco for 10 pounds.Oh, guess I should comment on the service. What service? We were attanted by at least 6 different people and, overall, it was not very nice. Especially not when one is reminded 68 min into the dinner that we only have the table for 120 min...so much for choosing this place for an anniversary dinner!We have lived in Hong Kong for 5+ years and know how fine Cantonese/Chinese food is supposed to taste. The Dim Sum at Hakkasan was spot on, but the rest was disappointing.Cannot recommend this restaurant and will not come back. Sorry!

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom

WOSaSGf5kjg-3e9I53CVmg.text: We had an amazing night in Hakkasan. Why then 4 stars you ask. It's probably more of a 4.5. When you  eat in a restaurant like Hakkasan you expect great food. The only part of the meal where they slipped were the starters which were average to good and not exceptional like the rest of the evening. We were a group of 5 who shared 5 different starters including the Dim Sum and had a 5 main dishes which we also shared a little. The main dishes were exceptional in every way. So was their signature cocktail. Most of them disappeared before we could take pictures :) If money is not an issue I highly recommend this delightful experience. Go with friends, share and enjoy.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Sea bass with honey.
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Duck cooked with truffles. It was delicious.

lFPQCcApNKa3MlUrM4f1YQ.text: This is one of those times where I wish Yelp offered half stars in their rating system. My experience at Hakkasan Mayfair was 3 1/2 stars. Hakkasan is a Michelin rated Chinese restaurant with a dark, intimate vibe. Definitely a dress up and show off your stuff type of place. Upon entering my co-worker and I were immediately greeted and escorted to our table. Even on a Tuesday night the place was packed. Our server came over and took our drink order first. I ordered one of their signature drinks, The Hakka, which had Belvedere vodka, Akashi-Tai sake, lychee, lime, coconut and passion fruit. It was excellent and flavorful but was disappointed to see my glass was only 2/3 full. That has always been a pet peeve of mine. Either use a smaller martini glass or fill it up.  As for our dinner, most things are appetizer or small plate sized and meant to be shared. We asked for suggestions from our server but he didn't seem to interested and gave us a few quick suggestions. Luckily my co-worker has spent time in the Orient and is more familiar with Asian cuisine. She asked me to trust her judgement in ordering (she did great!). We shared:*Dim Sum Platter - 6 pieces of Dim Sum. scallop shumai, har gau, Chinese chive dumpling, duck and yam bean dumpling. Each type featured 2 pieces each so my co-worker and I were able to try one of each. Very tasty and each one had a unique but equally good flavor and texture.*XO scallops stuffed in zucchini with royal pumpkin sauce. Scallops were fresh but sauce was pretty bland.  Not overly impressed.*Stir-fry Peking style duck with dried chilli, Szechuan pepper, baby leek and onion. Flavors were excellent. Not overly spicy but the right amount of kick to it. *Hakka noodles with shimeji mushroom, baby leek and salted turnip. Absolutely delicious! Flavors were perfect and amazing.During dinner I ordered a second cocktail and was again disappointed with a 2/3 full martini. I'm a drinker and have no problem spending good money on alcohol but don't skimp your customers. Our server came back and offered a dessert menu but we both declined. We weren't stuffed but satisfied. I'm still not sure what to think about the experience. The food was great even excellent but the wait staff seemed uninterested. The atmosphere at Hakkasan was hip, trendy and beautifully decorated. Seemed a little show offish and snobby though. Not exactly a welcoming atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. XO scallops wrapped with zucchini in a pumpkin sauce.  Scallops were fresh but sauce and flavor uneventful.
Photo of Hakkasan Mayfair - London, United Kingdom. Peking duck and Hakka noodles.  Both are amazing.

riTeuVckP1hrmU_7zrEijw.text: A nice luxury chinese restaurant in London. Immersion in a different world with loud electronic music, dark light and a lot of waiters in black and waitresses in blue.The food was very tasty - not necessary to take more than a small eat and main dish. Only bad point: the desert, a bit boring.

DN4XKdPZJde5xre7vmN_YA.text: This restaurant has been recommended to me by a colleague.  Upon research, we found great reviews.  The expectation was extremely met.  Food were great, service was good and atmosphere and ambiance is super.  We did the lunch tasting menu and there were so much food.   Far more than what expected and paid for.  We will definitely go back next time we are in town.

B9_4wKeF-Fv_6d2I0F_YgQ.text: Date of Visit: 26.12.17Time: 6.30pm"Great food, service and decor. Will never disappoint. "Review: I have not been to Hakkasan in a while so it was nice to visit again. Bruton Street may not be the busiest of London streets but its proximity to Berkley Sq and both Oxford Street and Regent Street makes it a good location. You are first greeted by the door staff and then down the dark corridor towards the coat check and then through to the reception desk where you are seen by around 5 or more people it seems, all dressed in blue and feels a little intimidating to start as you don't know who to talk to but everyone is friendly and you are soon seen to your table. There is the ground floor and lower ground area. You are served with menus and friendly service from the start. Also all very efficient with all members of staff being attentive and looking out for eye contact. Its nice that each branch have their own signature drinks and food items. The menu has changed since my last visit but we were guided through some options and went with those. Drinks arrived promptly followed by the food which arrived at the right temperature. Food cooked perfectly and the portion size was just right as nothing went to waste. I always like to try a mocktail or two but sometimes it can be difficult to find something that even sounds appetising. Even though the ingredients for the Kumquat Pomme Fizz does not sound like it would work i found it extremely refreshing and happy I went with this. The chicken was cooked well however it could have been a little more spicy and a little more sauce but i still enjoyed it and would order this again. It was also served with some light noodles which were cooked to perfection. The stir fry comes in one large pile so i am not sure how others eat this with chop sticks as it is hard to separate into smaller portions. But you soon get used to it. Again this dish was cooked well but a little too watery at the end but again happy with the recommendations as this also shows the staff know their dishes.  I went with a vegetarian and plenty of options available, more mushroom and tofu dishes though so do bear this in mind if you are not a fan of either. Dress code: From the website, Smart casual. No sportswear. Jeans are permitted as long as they are worn smartly with shoes and a collared shirt. Smart shorts suitable for lunch service but not dinner. Please do not wear hats inside. However I was only aware of this after my visit and looking at the website. Booking Process: A simple phone call on the day and i was able to make a reservation within 30mins which was perfect as I was round the corner where the wait was around an hour so this worked out well. Location: 17 Bruton Street, London, W1J 6QBParking: Street Parking outside but you are in London so you may need to drive around. Decor & Lighting: The two Hakkasan's i have been to have a similar style and its dark floors, walls and mood lighting all very stylistic. I remember the first time i went to the Mayfair branch it was so dark people had to use their mobiles and turn on the torch just to see the menu and this was during the day! But things have changed with lights over the tables which really help. Ambience & Acoustics: Light background music and easy to talk without the need to raise your voice, so just right, considering the area is mainly hard services they have done a good job to control the acoustics.Drinks:  Kumquat Pomme Fizz - apple, kumquat, lime and ginger ale. Food: Sanpei chicken claypot with sweet basil, chilli and spring onion & Stir-fry morning glory in chilli, ginger and preserved bean curd sauceBill / Cost: £77.41Conclusion: A really pleasant resturant where the food and service is always good. At around £40 per head without alcohol is fairly reasonable for the quality of food. I would recommend a visit for business, family, or any occasion. Rating: 8.5 out of 10.0

qgSga5WHYlPLK35HgGHJVQ.text: Food was amazing when we got it. Not a great experience despite this place having such a great reputation. We were seated as soon as we arrived and left to wait at least 15minutes before the waiter came to give us menus this seemed to be the norm throughout the whole evening. Only attended to when we had to call the waiter ourselves. Starters arrived which was really nice. But mains was another story only the rice and 1 dish arrived, the other dishes were not served until 20 to 25 minutes later despite our requests. Didn't live up to the standard of Hakassan I don't think we will be going again.
